'''Alvin Lee''' (born '''Graham Anthony Barnes''', 19 December 1944 – 6 March 2013) was a British guitarist and singer, best known as the lead guitarist and singer with the [[blues-rock]] band [[Ten Years After]].<!-- This article relates to a British subject, and should therefore have British spelling and punctuation. -->

==Biography==
He was born in [[Nottingham]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-21688814 |title=Alvin Lee, rock guitarist in the band Ten Years After, dies at 68 |publisher=BBC News |date=6 March 2013}}</ref> and attended the Margaret Glen-Bott School in [[Wollaton]]<ref>[http://www.alvinlee.de/alvinlee_bio.htm Alvinlee.de Biography]. Retrieved 7 March 2013</ref> which was a precursor to [[Comprehensive School]]s with [[Grammar School|grammar]] and [[Secondary Modern School|secondary modern]] streams.<ref>[http://www.lentontimes.co.uk/streets/margaret_glen_school.htm Margaret Glen-Bott School at Lenton times]. Retrieved 7 March 2013</ref>
He began playing guitar at the age of 13, and with [[Leo Lyons]] formed the core of the band [[Ten Years After]] in 1960. Influenced by his parents' collection of [[jazz]] and [[blues]] [[gramophone record|records]], it was the advent of [[rock and roll]] that sparked his interest, and guitarists such as [[Chuck Berry]] and [[Scotty Moore]] provided his inspiration.

Lee began to play professionally in 1962, in a band named the Jaybirds, who enjoyed popularity in their native England, but moved on to seek a wider fan-base. They began that year to perform in the [[Star-Club]] in Hamburg, Germany, following closely behind [[The Beatles]]. There, with Alvin Lee assuming the permanent role of lead vocalist in addition to that of lead guitarist, they began to build a following. It was not until the band moved to London in 1966 and changed its name, first to Jaybird, dropping 'The' and 's' to make it sound more contemporary; then to Blues Yard (for one [[concert|gig]] at the [[Marquee Club]]); and finally to [[Ten Years After]], that international success beckoned. The band secured a residency at the Marquee Club, and an invitation to the Windsor Jazz & Blues Festival in 1967 led to their first [[recording contract]]. The self-titled début album received [[airplay]] on San Francisco's [[underground music]] radio stations and was embraced by listeners, including concert promoter [[Bill Graham (promoter)|Bill Graham]], who invited the band to tour the United States for the first time in 1968. Ten Years After would ultimately tour the US twenty-eight times in seven years – more than any other UK band.{{Citation needed|date=July 2013}}

Lee's performance at the [[Woodstock Festival]] was captured on film in the documentary of the event, and his 'lightning-fast' playing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cricklewood-green-mw0000650879 |title=Cricklewood Green – Ten Years After : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref> helped catapult him to stardom.<ref name="NME Rock 'N' Roll Years">{{cite book
| first= John
| last= Tobler
| year= 1992
| title= NME Rock 'N' Roll Years
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Reed International Books Ltd
| location= London
| page= 201
| id= CN 5585
| isbn= 0-600-57602-7}}</ref> Soon the band was playing arenas and stadiums around the globe. The film brought Lee's music to a worldwide audience, although he later lamented that he missed the lost freedom and spiritual dedication with his earlier public.<ref name="Three Days That Rocked the World">{{cite book
| year= 2009
| title= Woodstock: Three Days That Rocked the World
| edition= 
| publisher= Sterling Publishing Co
| location= New York
| page= 193
| isbn= 978-1-4027-6623-7}}</ref> 

Lee was named "the Fastest guitarist in the West", and considered a precursor to [[Shred guitar|shred]]-style playing that would develop in the 1980s.<ref name="Legends of Rock Guitar">{{cite book
|author=Pete Brown, Harvey P. Newquist
| year= 1997
| title= Legends of Rock Guitar: The Essential Reference of Rock's Greatest Guitarists
| edition= 
| publisher= Hal Leonard Corp.
| location= Milwaukee WI
| page= 197
|url=http://books.google.com/books/about/Legends_of_Rock_Guitar.html?id=60Jde3l7WNwC
| isbn= 0-7935-4042-9}}</ref>

Ten Years After had success, releasing ten albums together, but by 1973, Lee was feeling limited by the band's style. Moving to Columbia Records had resulted in a radio hit song, "I'd Love To Change the World", but Lee preferred blues-rock to the pop to which the label steered them. He left Ten Years After after their second Columbia LP. With American [[Christian rock]] singer [[Mylon LeFevre]] and [[George Harrison]], [[Steve Winwood]], [[Ronnie Wood]] and [[Mick Fleetwood]], he [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] and released ''[[On the Road to Freedom]]'', an acclaimed album that was at the forefront of [[country rock]]. Also in 1973 he sat in on the Jerry Lee Lewis double album ''The Session'' recorded in London featuring many other guest stars including [[Albert Lee]], [[Peter Frampton]] and [[Rory Gallagher]]. A year later, in response to a dare, Lee formed Alvin Lee & Company to play a show at the [[Rainbow (London)|Rainbow]] in London and released it as a double live album, ''[[In Flight (Alvin Lee album)|In Flight]]''. Various members of the band continued on with Lee for his next two albums, ''[[Pump Iron!]]'' and ''[[Let It Rock (Alvin Lee album)|Let It Rock]]''. In late 1975, he played guitar for a couple of tracks on [[Bo Diddley]]'s ''The 20th Anniversary of Rock 'n' Roll'' all-star album. He finished out the 1970s with an outfit called "Ten Years Later" which released two albums, ''[[Rocket Fuel (Alvin Lee album)|Rocket Fuel]]'' (1978) and ''[[Ride On (Alvin Lee album)|Ride On]]'' (1979), and toured extensively throughout Europe and the United States.

The 1980s brought another change in Lee's direction, with two albums that were collaborations with [[Rare Bird]]'s [[Steve Gould (musician)|Steve Gould]], and a tour with the former [[John Mayall]] and [[Rolling Stones]]' guitarist [[Mick Taylor]] joining his band.

Lee's overall musical output includes more than twenty albums, including 1985's ''[[Detroit Diesel (Alvin Lee album)|Detroit Diesel]]'', 1989's [[About Time (Ten Years After album)|''About Time'' (Ten Years After album)]], recorded in [[Memphis]] with producer [[Terry Manning]], and the back to back 1990s collections of ''[[Zoom (Alvin Lee album)|Zoom]]'' and ''[[Nineteen Ninety-Four (Alvin Lee album)|Nineteen Ninety-Four]]'' (US title ''I Hear You Rockin' ''). Guest [[musician|artists]] on both albums included George Harrison.

''In Tennessee'', recorded with [[Scotty Moore]] and [[D. J. Fontana]], was released in 2004. Lee's last album, ''Still on the Road to Freedom'', was released in September 2012.

Lee died on 6 March 2013 in Spain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-207_162-57572963/guitarist-alvin-lee-of-ten-years-after-dies-at-68/ |title=Guitarist Alvin Lee of Ten Years After dies at 68 |publisher=CBS News |date=6 March 2013<!--, 8:34 PM-->}}</ref> According to his website, he died from "unforeseen complications following a routine surgical procedure".<ref>{{cite web|author=Rob Power |url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/guitars/ten-years-afters-alvin-lee-dies-571954 |title=Ten Years After's Alvin Lee dies |publisher=MusicRadar |date=6 March 2013<!--, 16:08 GMT-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereoboard.com/content/view/177754/9 |title=Ten Years After Singer And Guitarist Alvin Lee Dies Aged 68 |publisher=Stereoboard UK |date=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediabiz.de/musik/news/alvin-lee-von-ten-years-after-verstorben/330348 | title=Alvin Lee von Ten Years After verstorben | accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> He was 68. His former bandmates lamented his death. [[Leo Lyons]] called him "the closest thing I had to a brother", while [[Ric Lee]] (no relation) said "I don't think it's even sunk in yet as to the reality of his passing". ''Billboard'' highlighted such landmark performances as "[[Undead (Ten Years After album)|I'm Going Home]]" from the Woodstock festival and his 1971 hit single "[[I'd Love to Change the World]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Schneider|first=Marc|title=Alvin Lee of Ten Years After Dead at 68|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1550730/alvin-lee-of-ten-years-after-dead-at-68|work=[[Billboard Magazine]]|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
